DataElement.preferredName: Hematopoietic Cell Graft Alteration Antibody Administered Specify Text
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The free-text field to describe the antibodies administered during the hematopoietic cell product (graft) manipilation.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Hematopoietic Cell Graft Alteration Antibody Administered
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Primitive blood cells derived from embryonic mesenchyme capable of differentiating into any of the blood cell line progenitor cells (erythroblasts, young granulocytic series cells, megakaryocytes, etc.)_Healthy skin, bone, or other tissue taken from one part of the body and used to replace diseased or injured tissue removed from another part of the body._A change resulting in something that is different from the original._A type of protein made by B lymphocytes in response to a foreign substance (antigen). Each antibody only binds to a specific antigen, helping to destroy the antigen directly or by assisting white blood cells to destroy the antigen._The act of having given something (e.g., a medication or test).

ObjectClass.preferredName: Hematopoietic Stem Cell Graft Alteration Antibody
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Primitive blood cells derived from embryonic mesenchyme capable of differentiating into any of the blood cell line progenitor cells (erythroblasts, young granulocytic series cells, megakaryocytes, etc.):Healthy skin, bone, or other tissue taken from one part of the body and used to replace diseased or injured tissue removed from another part of the body.:A change resulting in something that is different from the original.:(AN-tih-BOD-ee) A type of protein made by certain white blood cells in response to a foreign substance (antigen). Each antibody can bind to only a specific antigen. The purpose of this binding is to help destroy the antigen. Antibodies can work in several ways, depending on the nature of the antigen. Some antibodies destroy antigens directly. Others make it easier for white blood cells to destroy the antigen.

Concepts.definition: Primitive blood cells derived from embryonic mesenchyme capable of differentiating into any of the blood cell line progenitor cells (erythroblasts, young granulocytic series cells, megakaryocytes, etc.)
Tissue or organ transplanted from a donor to a recipient.
The act or process of modifying something.

A type of protein made by B lymphocytes in response to a foreign substance (antigen). Each antibody only binds to a specific antigen, helping to destroy the antigen directly or by assisting white blood cells to destroy the antigen.
The act of having given something (e.g., a medication or test).
